Each [G:C(a)] must be a power of p (since it divides |G| = p^2). Also, C(a) is a proper subgroup of G, so [G:C(a)] is either p or p^2. If [G:C(a)] = p^2, then a is in the center which is a contradiction. Thus each [G:C(a)] = p.  Therefore, p^2 = |Z(G)| + kp for some integer k.  This means p divides |Z(G)|.  So |Z(G)| can be p or p^2.  If |Z(G)| = p^2, then Z(G) = G, and G is Abelian.  If |Z(G)| = p, then G/Z(G) has order p, and any group of prime order is cyclic.
